metadata.template_skill: Student answers diagnostic questions confirming denominator constancy across the 1 boundary

telemetry_data.mastery_skill: Student can identify that the denominator stays constant when counting past 1

steps.dialogue: Look at these fractions on the number line: 2/3, then 3/3, then 4/3. Notice what's happening with the bottom number.

prompt.text: After 3/3 comes 4/3. What happened to the denominator?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the bottom number in each fraction on the number line. What number do you see there?

Let's examine this more carefully. Look at the bottom number in 2/3. It's 3. Now look at the bottom number in 3/3. Still 3. And in 4/3? Also 3. The denominator tells us what size pieces we're counting - and we're always counting thirds.

Let me walk you through this. When we count by thirds, the denominator - that bottom number - always stays 3. Look at the sequence: 2/3 has 3 on the bottom, 3/3 has 3 on the bottom, and 4/3 has 3 on the bottom. The denominator never changes because we're always working with thirds - pieces that are one-third in size. Only the top number, the numerator, changes as we count more thirds. So the denominator stayed the same at 3. That's how denominators work - they stay constant when we're counting with the same size pieces.

on_correct.dialogue: Right, the denominator stays the same.
